description: Inherited from Middle English barbarik, from Old French barbarique (“barbarous”), from Latin barbaricus, from Ancient Greek βαρβαρικός (barbarikós, “barbaric, savage, fierce”), from βάρβαρος (bárbaros, “barbarian”) +‎ -ικός (-ikós, adjective suffix). See βάρβαρος (bárbaros) for more.

adjectives.description: barbaric (comparative more barbaric, superlative most barbaric)

entries.meaning: of or relating to a barbarian; uncivilized, uncultured or uncouth
examples: a barbaric attack on a doctor in a hospital
